He also had the same symptoms in the past 3 months, treated with ibuprofen, which was not beneficial to his pain. MCV: 80 fL
Hemoglobin electrophoresis: 60% HbS, 5% HbF, 35% HbA2
AST: 40 U/L
ALT: 35 U/L

Query:
###Human: This is a 55-year-old female with a past medical history of rare migraines, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and polycystic ovary syndrome/infertility who presented with symptoms of cholecystitis and was found incidentally to have a large pericardial effusion. A pericardiocentesis was performed, and the fluid analysis was consistent with primary cardiac lymphoma. Pericardial fluid was positive for light chain restricted B cells expressing FMC-7, CD19, CD20, and myc rearrangement consistent with B-cell lymphoma. A subsequent lumbar puncture and bone marrow biopsy were negative for any involvement, indicating primary cardiac lymphoma. A cardiac MRI showed a mass that was 5 cm x 7 cm on the lateral wall of the right atrium adjacent to the AV junction.

Past Medical History:
Rare migraines
Hypertension
Hyperlipidemia
Polycystic ovary syndrome/infertility
Viral encephalitis/meningitis-->ICH-->seizure/stroke (date not provided) - from severe sinus infection, caused mild non-focal residual deficits
CSF leak with meningitis status post lumbar drain placement
Right lower extremity deep vein thrombosis status post inferior vena cava (IVC) filter placement
Previous knee surgery
